featured.text: As many as 60 pilot whales swam ashore.
These seagoing mammals are among the lucky survivors of a whale-stranding last December at Cape Cod.
Scientists are still trying to find out why whales have this self-destructive behavior.
Many of the whales died on the beach—crushed by their own weight.
Only a few people worked with the whales so that they would not become too accustomed to human beings.

other.text: Early this past summer the three whales were pronounced fit enough to be returned to the Atlantic Ocean.
They were found in a group of 50 whales about 60 miles from where they had seen set free.
The 60 pilot whales swam ashore as a result of (A) a large winter storm off the coast of Cape Cod. (B) a behavior currently unknown to scientists.
The three whales were taken in a van to the New England Aquarium in Boston, Mass.
A month after their release, the whales were spotted.
The pilot whales died on the beaches of Cape Cod due to (A) the lack of salt water to facilitate their respiration.
Whale experts found Tag, Notch, Baby alive.
The three whales Tag, Notch, and Baby were rescued because (A) younger whales have a greater chance of survival than the others.
Scientists are studying the suicidal behavior of pilot whales.

definition.zh_def: 鯨魚：一種大型的海洋哺乳動物，屬於鯨目，通常以浮游生物和小魚為食。
definition.en_def: A large marine mammal belonging to the order Cetacea, typically feeding on plankton and small fish.
definition.example: The whale swam gracefully through the ocean waves.
